content.description:
A few easy moves up to gain the horizontal finger crack which you follow right towards the bolt in the obvious dihedral along the black streak.  Upper half shared with Puss 'n Boots.

The traverse in the beginning is exciting but I found the crux to be the committing move standing up out of the horizontal crack and moving past the bolt to gain a good hand in the upper dihedral.
content.protection: Small cams up to 3". 1 bolt in the middle. 2 Bolt anchor at the top
content.location:
Found just right of Hungry Tiger this route shares an upper portion with Puss 'n Boots.

Look for the right deep traversing finger crack in the beginning.

content.description:
Start with two opposing rails into a bumping crimp onto a downward sidepull with slick left foot. Crimps and more rails follow throughout the route.

Crux between bolt 2/3. 12b/c after​.

Can't find any info on route grade, setter, or FA. All topos have a ? And no info from community. Looking for details thank you.
content.location: Left of tiger by the tail

content.description: Start up a short and stout finger crack and encounter a crux near the end of the crack.  Clip a piton, place a piece or two, and head up on steeper terrain to the bolt.  Place another piece and go up and left to the anchor above the lip.  This is the best route at the crag and is not to be missed.
content.protection: Doubles .3 to .75 with one #1 or #2 (all in camalot sizes).  There is a pin and a bolt after the finger crack.  There is a two-bolt anchor.
content.location: This is on Tiger Wall.  Locate the obvious shallow right-leaning finger crack.

content.description: Start on sharp flaky holds just to the left of the crack. Put a sling on a notch and head up a few moves until you are able to traverse right into the crack. Place a piece or two and head straight up to the start of the powerful and difficult climbing. Layback up, clip a bolt, and traverse on "jugs."  Do a few moves in the crack then grab a small crimp out right and struggle your way to the top. This is the way we climbed the route, but there might be a more direct start up the crack that is better protected. The way we climbed seemed like the path of least resistance. Boom. Meow.
content.protection: .3-.75 (doubles) with some slings for the start and anchor. There is one bolt at the crux. There are open cold shuts as well as 2 glue-ins further up.
content.location: Right side of the Tiger Wall just before Tigerlily. Locate a burly looking crack that pinches to a seam and start just to the left.

content.description: This climb ascends a black streak up the wall past broken seams. The route starts with pulling a roof, followed by thin technical moves all the way to the top.
content.protection:
-4 bolts (bolt 1 is a good 5/16 buttonhead, bolt 2 is good but has mixed metals (CS bolt + SS hanger), bolt 3 & 4 are stainless and new as of August 2019)

-finger to hand sized cams for start

-good TR (top anchor is 2 cold shuts and a 3rd SS bolt with hanger above them which was added in late 2018 or early 2019)

content.description: The crux is right off the ground with another in the middle depending on your height. Start with a sinker jam, plug in some pro and move to the face with some hard 5.11 iron cross action. Pull back into the wonderful crack and plug more pro and 2 bolts right next to each other before encountering the 2nd crux for those under 5.11. At the mini roof make a long reach or hop up the face to a horizontal. Move about 7ft left on the horizontal to a right facing hand crack and then choose between a dirty but sinker hands crack to a killer horn for the top out hold on the left OR a very thin fingers and tips crack that tops out to the right (difficulty unknown to me)
content.protection: A set of cams with a couple extras in the hands and tight hands size and 2 quickdraws (or a pre-equalized sliding x) for two hangers that are 1 foot apart protecting the second crux. There are closed anchors on the top that can also be used for top roping but are about 4' back from the edge.
content.location: Located on the Tiger Wall on the lower tier. It's the first route on the left side of the lower tier easily located by the overhanging bulge.

content.description: A predominately Off-width crack(at least for my little hands) that can be climbed without many mandatory offwidth moves. Although knee jams and chicken wings will assist with resting near the top. There are holds along the crack for some strong-guy climbing that's sustained, pumpy, and really fun all the way through.
content.protection:
Two, shiny, Glue-in bolts at the top. Can be a well protected lead with the necessary wide pro to 5" and long sleeves.

Getting to the top-rope bolts is a sketchy affair, they're located on a sloping ledge right by the edge of the wall. you can build an anchor and lower down to them.
content.location: Near the left-center of the Tiger Wall, before it drops off. the crack is stained black and located directly under the roof where Tiger By The Tail(5.11c) ends.
